1.text: THERESA MAY: A little over six months ago, the British people voted for change.

7.text:
They voted to shape a brighter future for
our country.

11.text: They voted to leave the European Union and embrace the world.

16.text: And they did so with their eyes open: accepting that the road ahead will be uncertain at times,

23.text: but believing that it leads towards a brighter future for their children - and their grandchildren too.

30.text: And it is the job of this Government to deliver it. That means more than negotiating our new

36.text:
relationship with the EU. It means taking
the opportunity of this great moment of national

43.text: change to step back and ask ourselves what kind of country we want to be.

51.text: My answer is clear. I want this United Kingdom to emerge from this period of change stronger,

59.text: fairer, more united and more outward-looking than ever before. I want us to be a secure,

68.text:
prosperous, tolerant country - a magnet for
international talent and a home to the pioneers

74.text: and innovators who will shape the world ahead. I want us to be a truly Global Britain – the

81.text:
best friend and neighbour to our European
partners, but a country that reaches beyond

87.text:
the borders of Europe too. A country that
gets out into the world to build relationships

93.text: with old friends and new allies alike.

97.text: I want Britain to be what we have the potential, talent and ambition to be. A great, global

104.text:
trading nation that is respected around the
world and strong, confident and united at home.

114.text:
That is why this Government has a Plan for
Britain. One that gets us the right deal abroad

121.text:
but also ensures we get a better deal for
ordinary working people at home.

126.text:
It’s why that plan sets out how we will
use this moment of change to build a stronger

133.text:
economy and a fairer society by embracing
genuine economic and social reform.

140.text:
Why our new Modern Industrial Strategy is
being developed, to ensure every nation and

145.text: area of the United Kingdom can make the most of the opportunities ahead. Why we will go

151.text: further to reform our schools to ensure every child has the knowledge and the skills they

156.text:
need to thrive in post-Brexit Britain. Why
as we continue to bring the deficit down,

163.text: we will take a balanced approach by investing in our economic infrastructure - because it

169.text:
can transform the growth potential of our
economy, and improve the quality of people’s

174.text:
lives across the whole country.
It’s why we will put the preservation of

179.text: our precious Union at the heart of everything we do. Because it is only by coming together

186.text: as one great union of nations and people that we can make the most of the opportunities

191.text: ahead. The result of the referendum was not a decision

197.text:
to turn inward and retreat from the world.
Because Britain’s history and culture is

203.text:
profoundly internationalist.
We are a European country – and proud of

208.text:
our shared European heritage – but we are
also a country that has always looked beyond

214.text:
Europe to the wider world. That is why we
are one of the most racially diverse countries

220.text: in Europe, one of the most multicultural members of the European Union, and why – whether

226.text: we are talking about India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, America, Australia, Canada, New Zealand, countries

232.text:
in Africa or those that are closer to home
in Europe – so many of us have close friends

237.text:
and relatives from across the world.
Instinctively, we want to travel to, study

244.text:
in, trade with countries not just in Europe
but beyond the borders of our continent. Even

250.text:
now as we prepare to leave the EU, we are
planning for the next biennial Commonwealth

256.text:
Heads of Government meeting in 2018 – a
reminder of our unique and proud global relationships.

263.text:
And it is important to recognise this fact.
June the 23rd was not the moment Britain chose

272.text: to step back from the world. It was the moment we chose to build a truly Global Britain.

279.text:
I know that this – and the other reasons
Britain took such a decision – is not always

284.text: well understood among our friends and allies in Europe. And I know many fear that this

289.text: might herald the beginning of a greater unravelling of the EU.

294.text:
But let me be clear: I do not want that to
happen. It would not be in the best interests

301.text:
of Britain. It remains overwhelmingly and
compellingly in Britain’s national interest

307.text: that the EU should succeed. And that is why I hope in the months and years ahead we will

313.text:
all reflect on the lessons of Britain’s
decision to leave.

318.text:
So let me take this opportunity to set out
the reasons for our decision and to address

323.text:
the people of Europe directly.
It’s not simply because our history and

329.text: culture is profoundly internationalist, important though that is. Many in Britain have always

336.text:
felt that the United Kingdom’s place in
the European Union came at the expense of

341.text:
our global ties, and of a bolder embrace of
free trade with the wider world.

346.text:
There are other important reasons too.
Our political traditions are different. Unlike

353.text: other European countries, we have no written constitution, but the principle of Parliamentary

358.text:
Sovereignty is the basis of our unwritten
constitutional settlement. We have only a

364.text: recent history of devolved governance – though it has rapidly embedded itself - and we have

369.text:
little history of coalition government. The
public expect to be able to hold their governments

375.text:
to account very directly, and as a result
supranational institutions as strong as those

383.text: created by the European Union sit very uneasily in relation to our political history and way

389.text: of life. And, while I know Britain might at times have

393.text: been seen as an awkward member state, the European Union has struggled to deal with

398.text:
the diversity of its member countries and
their interests. It bends towards uniformity,

405.text:
not flexibility. David Cameron’s negotiation
was a valiant final attempt to make it work

412.text:
for Britain - and I want to thank all those
elsewhere in Europe who helped him reach an

418.text: agreement - but the blunt truth, as we know, is that there was not enough flexibility on

424.text: many important matters for a majority of British voters.

428.text: Now I do not believe that these things apply uniquely to Britain. Britain is not the only

434.text: member state where there is a strong attachment to accountable and democratic government,

438.text:
such a strong internationalist mindset, or
a belief that diversity within Europe should

443.text:
be celebrated. And so I believe there is a
lesson in Brexit not just for Britain but,

448.text:
if it wants to succeed, for the EU itself.
Because our continent’s great strength has

455.text:
always been its diversity. And there are two
ways of dealing with different interests.

461.text: You can respond by trying to hold things together by force, tightening a vice-like grip that

466.text:
ends up crushing into tiny pieces the very
things you want to protect. Or you can respect

472.text:
difference, cherish it even, and reform the
EU so that it deals better with the wonderful

477.text:
diversity of its member states.
So to our friends across Europe, let me say

483.text: this. Our vote to leave the European Union was no

486.text: rejection of the values we share. The decision to leave the EU represents no desire to become

492.text: more distant to you, our friends and neighbours.  It was no attempt to do harm to the EU itself

499.text:
or to any of its remaining member states.
We do not want to turn the clock back to the

506.text: days when Europe was less peaceful, less secure and less able to trade freely. It was a vote

511.text:
to restore, as we see it, our parliamentary
democracy, national self-determination, and

518.text: to become even more global and internationalist in action and in spirit.

525.text:
We will continue to be reliable partners,
willing allies and close friends. We want

531.text: to buy your goods and services, sell you ours, trade with you as freely as possible, and

536.text:
work with one another to make sure we are
all safer, more secure and more prosperous

542.text: through continued friendship. You will still be welcome in this country

546.text:
as we hope our citizens will be welcome in
yours. At a time when together we face a serious

552.text:
threat from our enemies, Britain’s unique
intelligence capabilities will continue to

557.text: help to keep people in Europe safe from terrorism. And at a time when there is growing concern

563.text: about European security, Britain’s servicemen and women, based in European countries including

569.text:
Estonia, Poland and Romania, will continue
to do their duty.

575.text:
We are leaving the European Union, but we
are not leaving Europe.

581.text: And that is why we seek a new and equal partnership – between an independent, self-governing,

587.text:
Global Britain and our friends and allies
in the EU.

592.text: Not partial membership of the European Union, associate membership of the European Union,

598.text:
or anything that leaves us half-in, half-out.
We do not seek to adopt a model already enjoyed

605.text:
by other countries. We do not seek to hold
on to bits of membership as we leave.

611.text: No, the United Kingdom is leaving the European Union. And my job is to get the right deal

617.text:
for Britain as we do.
So today I want to outline our objectives

625.text: for the negotiation ahead. 12 objectives that amount to one big goal: a new, positive and

633.text: constructive partnership between Britain and the European Union.

637.text: And as we negotiate that partnership, we will be driven by some simple principles: we will

645.text:
provide as much certainty and clarity as we
can at every stage. And we will take this

651.text: opportunity to make Britain stronger, to make Britain fairer, and to build a more Global

656.text: Britain too. The first objective is crucial. We will provide

664.text:
certainty wherever we can.
We are about to enter a negotiation. That

670.text: means there will be give and take. There will have to be compromises. It will require imagination

676.text: on both sides. And not everybody will be able to know everything at every stage.

683.text: But I recognise how important it is to provide business, the public sector, and everybody

689.text: with as much certainty as possible as we move through the process.

694.text: So where we can offer that certainty, we will do so.

699.text:
That is why last year we acted quickly to
give clarity about farm payments and university

704.text: funding. And it is why, as we repeal the European Communities

708.text:
Act, we will convert the “acquis” – the
body of existing EU law – into British law.

715.text: This will give the country maximum certainty as we leave the EU. The same rules and laws

721.text:
will apply on the day after Brexit as they
did before. And it will be for the British

727.text: Parliament to decide on any changes to that law after full scrutiny and proper Parliamentary

734.text: debate. And when it comes to Parliament, there is

738.text: one other way in which I would like to provide certainty. I can confirm today that the Government

743.text: will put the final deal that is agreed between the UK and the EU to a vote in both Houses

749.text:
of Parliament, before it comes into force.
Our second guiding principle is to build a

757.text: stronger Britain. That means taking control of our own affairs,

763.text: as those who voted in their millions to leave the European Union demanded we must.

768.text: So we will take back control of our laws and bring an end to the jurisdiction of the European

773.text: Court of Justice in Britain. Leaving the European Union will mean that

777.text: our laws will be made in Westminster, Edinburgh, Cardiff and Belfast. And those laws will be

783.text: interpreted by judges not in Luxembourg but in courts across this country.

789.text: Because we will not have truly left the European Union if we are not in control of our own

794.text: laws. A stronger Britain demands that we do something

799.text: else - strengthen the precious union between the four nations of the United Kingdom.

805.text: At this momentous time, it is more important than ever that we face the future together,

812.text:
united by what makes us strong: the bonds
that unite us as a people, and our shared

818.text: interest in the UK being an open, successful trading nation in the future.

823.text:
And I hope that same spirit of unity will
apply in Northern Ireland in particular over

829.text: the coming months in the Assembly elections, and the main parties there will work together

834.text: to re-establish a partnership government as soon as possible.

839.text: Foreign affairs are of course the responsibility of the UK Government, and in dealing with

844.text:
them we act in the interests of all parts
of the United Kingdom. As Prime Minister,

850.text:
I take that responsibility seriously.
I have also been determined from the start

856.text: that the devolved administrations should be fully engaged in this process.

861.text: That is why the Government has set up a Joint Ministerial Committee on EU Negotiations,

866.text: so ministers from each of the UK’s devolved administrations can contribute to the process

871.text: of planning for our departure from the European Union.

875.text:
We have already received a paper from the
Scottish Government, and look forward to receiving

880.text: a paper from the Welsh Government shortly. Both papers will be considered as part of

885.text:
this important process. We won’t agree on
everything, but I look forward to working

891.text:
with the administrations in Scotland, Wales
and Northern Ireland to deliver a Brexit that

896.text:
works for the whole of the United Kingdom.
Part of that will mean working very carefully

903.text:
to ensure that – as powers are repatriated
from Brussels back to Britain – the right

908.text: powers are returned to Westminster, and the right powers are passed to the devolved administrations

914.text:
of Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.
As we do so, our guiding principle must be

920.text:
to ensure that - as we leave the European
Union - no new barriers to living and doing

926.text:
business within our own Union are created,
That means maintaining the necessary common

932.text: standards and frameworks for our own domestic market, empowering the UK as an open, trading

939.text:
nation to strike the best trade deals around
the world, and protecting the common resources

944.text: of our islands. And as we do this, I should equally be clear

948.text: that no decisions currently taken by the devolved administrations will be removed from them.

954.text: We cannot forget that, as we leave, the United Kingdom will share a land border with the

960.text: EU, and maintaining that Common Travel Area with the Republic of Ireland will be an important

966.text:
priority for the UK in the talks ahead.
There has been a Common Travel Area between

972.text: the United Kingdom and the Republic of Ireland for many years. Indeed, it was formed before

977.text: either of our two countries were members of the European Union. And the family ties and

982.text: bonds of affection that unite our two countries mean that there will always be a special relationship

988.text: between us. So we will work to deliver a practical solution

993.text: that allows the maintenance of the Common Travel Area with the Republic, while protecting

997.text: the integrity of the United Kingdom’s immigration system.

1002.text: Nobody wants to return to the borders of the past, so we will make it a priority to deliver

1008.text:
a practical solution as soon as we can.
The third principle is to build a fairer Britain.

1017.text:
That means ensuring it is fair to everyone
who lives and works in this country.

1022.text: And that is why we will ensure we can control immigration to Britain from Europe.

1028.text:
We will continue to attract the brightest
and the best to work or study in Britain – indeed

1033.text: openness to international talent must remain one of this country’s most distinctive assets

1039.text: – but that process must be managed properly so that our immigration system serves the

1044.text: national interest. So we will get control of the number of people

1048.text: coming to Britain from the EU. Because while controlled immigration can bring

1054.text:
great benefits – filling skills shortages,
delivering public services, making British

1060.text: businesses the world-beaters they often are – when the numbers get too high, public

1065.text:
support for the system falters.
In the last decade or so, we have seen record

1072.text:
levels of net migration in Britain, and that
sheer volume has put pressure on public services,

1077.text:
like schools, stretched our infrastructure,
especially housing, and put a downward pressure

1082.text: on wages for working class people. As Home Secretary for six years, I know that you cannot

1088.text:
control immigration overall when there is
free movement to Britain from Europe.

1093.text:
Britain is an open and tolerant country. We
will always want immigration, especially high-skilled

1099.text: immigration, we will always want immigration from Europe, and we will always welcome individual

1104.text:
migrants as friends. But the message from
the public before and during the referendum

1110.text: campaign was clear: Brexit must mean control of the number of people who come to Britain

1116.text: from Europe. And that is what we will deliver. Fairness demands that we deal with another

1124.text:
issue as soon as possible too. We want to
guarantee the rights of EU citizens who are

1130.text:
already living in Britain, and the rights
of British nationals in other member states,

1135.text: as early as we can.  I have told other EU leaders that we could

1139.text:
give people the certainty they want straight
away, and reach such a deal now.

1144.text: Many of them favour such an agreement - one or two others do not - but I want everyone

1150.text: to know that it remains an important priority for Britain – and for many other member

1155.text:
states – to resolve this challenge as soon
as possible. Because it is the right and fair

1161.text: thing to do. And a fairer Britain is a country that protects

1167.text: and enhances the rights people have at work. That is why, as we translate the body of European

1173.text:
law into our domestic regulations, we will
ensure that workers rights are fully protected

1179.text: and maintained. Indeed, under my leadership, not only will

1183.text: the Government protect the rights of workers’ set out in European legislation, we will build

1188.text: on them. Because under this Conservative Government, we will make sure legal protection for workers

1193.text: keeps pace with the changing labour market – and that the voices of workers are heard

1198.text:
by the boards of publicly-listed companies
for the first time.

1204.text:
But the great prize for this country – the
opportunity ahead – is to use this moment

1210.text:
to build a truly Global Britain. A country
that reaches out to old friends and new allies.

1217.text:
A great, global, trading nation. And one of
the firmest advocates for free trade anywhere

1224.text: in the world. That starts with our close friends and neighbours

1228.text:
in Europe. So as a priority, we will pursue
a bold and ambitious Free Trade Agreement

1235.text: with the European Union. This agreement should allow for the freest

1240.text: possible trade in goods and services between Britain and the EU’s member states. It should

1246.text: give British companies the maximum freedom to trade with and operate within European

1252.text:
markets – and let European businesses do
the same in Britain.

1257.text:
But I want to be clear. What I am proposing
cannot mean membership of the EU’s Single

1264.text: Market. European leaders have said many times that

1269.text: membership means accepting the “four freedoms” of goods, capital, services and people. And

1277.text: being out of the EU but a member of the Single Market would mean complying with the EU’s

1283.text:
rules and regulations that implement those
freedoms, without having a vote on what those

1288.text: rules and regulations are. It would mean accepting a role for the European Court of Justice that

1295.text: would see it still having direct legal authority in our country.

1299.text:
It would to all intents and purposes mean
not leaving the EU at all.

1307.text: And that is why both sides in the referendum campaign made it clear that a vote to leave

1312.text:
the EU would be a vote to leave the Single
Market.

1316.text: So we do not seek membership of the Single Market. Instead we seek the greatest possible

1323.text:
access to it through a new, comprehensive,
bold and ambitious Free Trade Agreement.

1331.text: That Agreement may take in elements of current Single Market arrangements in certain areas

1336.text:
– on the export of cars and lorries for
example, or the freedom to provide financial

1340.text:
services across national borders – as it
makes no sense to start again from scratch

1346.text: when Britain and the remaining Member States have adhered to the same rules for so many

1350.text: years. But I respect the position taken by European

1355.text: leaders who have been clear about their position, just as I am clear about mine. So an important

1361.text: part of the new strategic partnership we seek with the EU will be the pursuit of the greatest

1367.text:
possible access to the Single Market, on a
fully reciprocal basis, through a comprehensive

1373.text: Free Trade Agreement. And because we will no longer be members of

1378.text:
the Single Market, we will not be required
to contribute huge sums to the EU budget.

1383.text: There may be some specific European programmes in which we might want to participate. If

1389.text:
so, and this will be for us to decide, it
is reasonable that we should make an appropriate

1394.text:
contribution. But the principle is clear:
the days of Britain making vast contributions

1400.text:
to the European Union every year will end.
But it is not just trade with the EU we should

1408.text:
be interested in. A Global Britain must be
free to strike trade agreements with countries

1413.text:
from outside the European Union too.
Because important though our trade with the

1419.text:
EU is and will remain, it is clear that the
UK needs to increase significantly its trade

1426.text:
with the fastest growing export markets in
the world.

1431.text:
Since joining the EU, trade as a percentage
of GDP has broadly stagnated in the UK. That

1438.text:
is why it is time for Britain to get out into
the world and rediscover its role as a great,

1445.text: global, trading nation. This is such a priority for me that when I

1450.text: became Prime Minister I established, for the first time, a Department for International

1454.text: Trade, led by Liam Fox. We want to get out into the wider world, to

1462.text:
trade and do business all around the globe.
Countries including China, Brazil, and the

1468.text: Gulf States have already expressed their interest in striking trade deals with us. We have started

1473.text: discussions on future trade ties with countries like Australia, New Zealand and India. And

1479.text:
President Elect Trump has said Britain is
not “at the back of the queue” for a trade

1483.text:
deal with the United States, the world’s
biggest economy, but front of the line.

1489.text: I know my emphasis on striking trade agreements with countries outside Europe has led to questions

1495.text: about whether Britain seeks to remain a member of the EU’s Customs Union. And it is true

1502.text: that full Customs Union membership prevents us from negotiating our own comprehensive

1507.text: trade deals. Now, I want Britain to be able to negotiate

1512.text:
its own trade agreements. But I also want
tariff-free trade with Europe and cross-border

1518.text: trade there to be as frictionless as possible. That means I do not want Britain to be part

1524.text: of the Common Commercial Policy and I do not want us to be bound by the Common External

1529.text: Tariff. These are the elements of the Customs Union that prevent us from striking our own

1535.text: comprehensive trade agreements with other countries. But I do want us to have a customs

1540.text: agreement with the EU. Whether that means we must reach a completely

1545.text: new customs agreement, become an associate member of the Customs Union in some way, or

1550.text:
remain a signatory to some elements of it,
I hold no preconceived position. I have an

1556.text: open mind on how we do it. It is not the means that matter, but the ends.

1562.text:
And those ends are clear: I want to remove
as many barriers to trade as possible. And

1569.text:
I want Britain to be free to establish our
own tariff schedules at the World Trade Organisation,

1574.text: meaning we can reach new trade agreements not just with the European Union but with

1579.text: old friends and new allies from outside Europe too.

1583.text:
A Global Britain must also be a country that
looks to the future. That means being one

1592.text:
of the best places in the world for science
and innovation.

1596.text:
One of our great strengths as a nation is
the breadth and depth of our academic and

1602.text:
scientific communities, backed up by some
of the world’s best universities. And we

1607.text: have a proud history of leading and supporting cutting-edge research and innovation.

1613.text: So we will also welcome agreement to continue to collaborate with our European partners

1619.text:
on major science, research, and technology
initiatives.

1623.text:
From space exploration to clean energy to
medical technologies, Britain will remain

1629.text:
at the forefront of collective endeavours
to better understand, and make better, the

1634.text: world in which we live. And a Global Britain will continue to cooperate

1641.text: with its European partners in important areas such as crime, terrorism and foreign affairs.

1652.text:
All of us in Europe face the challenge of
cross-border crime, a deadly terrorist threat,

1659.text: and the dangers presented by hostile states. All of us share interests and values in common,

1667.text:
values we want to see projected around the
world.

1671.text: With the threats to our common security becoming more serious, our response cannot be to cooperate

1677.text:
with one another less, but to work together
more. I therefore want our future relationship

1684.text: with the European Union to include practical arrangements on matters of law enforcement

1689.text: and the sharing of intelligence material with our EU allies.

1693.text:
I am proud of the role Britain has played
and will continue to play in promoting Europe’s

1699.text: security. Britain has led Europe on the measures needed to keep our continent secure – whether

1705.text: it is implementing sanctions against Russia following its action in Crimea, working for

1709.text: peace and stability in the Balkans, or securing Europe’s external border. We will continue

1716.text:
to work closely with our European allies in
foreign and defence policy even as we leave

1722.text: the EU itself. These are our objectives for the negotiation

1728.text:
ahead – objectives that will help to realise
our ambition of shaping that stronger, fairer,

1735.text:
Global Britain that we want to see.
They are the basis for a new, strong, constructive

1740.text:
partnership with the European Union – a
partnership of friends and allies, of interests

1746.text:
and values. A partnership for a strong EU
and a strong UK.

1753.text:
But there is one further objective we are
setting. For as I have said before – it

1758.text:
is in no one’s interests for there to be
a cliff-edge for business or a threat to stability,

1764.text: as we change from our existing relationship to a new partnership with the EU.

1769.text: By this, I do not mean that we will seek some form of unlimited transitional status, in

1775.text: which we find ourselves stuck forever in some kind of permanent political purgatory. That

1780.text:
would not be good for Britain, but nor do
I believe it would be good for the EU.

1785.text: Instead, I want us to have reached an agreement about our future partnership by the time the

1791.text: two-year Article Fifty process has concluded. From that point onwards, we believe a phased

1797.text: process of implementation, in which both Britain and the EU institutions and member states

1804.text:
prepare for the new arrangements that will
exist between us will be in our mutual self-interest.

1810.text: This will give businesses enough time to plan and prepare for those new arrangements.

1816.text: This might be about our immigration controls, customs systems or the way in which we cooperate

1821.text:
on criminal justice matters. Or it might be
about the future legal and regulatory framework

1825.text:
for financial services. For each issue, the
time we need to phase-in the new arrangements

1830.text:
may differ. Some might be introduced very
quickly, some might take longer. And the interim

1836.text:
arrangements we rely upon are likely to be
a matter of negotiation.

1841.text:
But the purpose is clear: we will work to
avoid a disruptive cliff-edge, and we will

1847.text: do everything we can to phase in the new arrangements we require as Britain and the EU move towards

1854.text: our new partnership. So, these are the objectives we have set.

1863.text:
Certainty wherever possible. Control of our
own laws. Strengthening the United Kingdom.

1869.text: Maintaining the Common Travel Area with Ireland. Control of immigration. Rights for EU nationals

1874.text:
in Britain, and British nationals in the EU.
Enhancing rights for workers. Free trade with

1880.text: European markets. New trade agreements with other countries. A leading role in science

1885.text: and innovation. Cooperation on crime, terrorism and foreign affairs. And a phased approach,

1891.text:
delivering a smooth and orderly Brexit.
